questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD  with complaints of lower limb weakness. He was diagnosed with neurolathyrism. Which of the following vitamin supplementation may prove useful in reversing this condition?
questions.solution:
A patient presenting with lower limb weakness and diagnosed with neurolathyrism may benefit from vitamin C supplementation to help reverse the condition.

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to a red gram or Bengal gram. It is mostly consumed by poor agricultural laborers because it is relatively cheap. Lathyrism is more prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Odisha, and Bihar. The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/ split/ flour). 

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing this disease. It is water-soluble and can be removed by the following methods:

  • Soaking pulses in hot water and discarding the water 
  • Overnight soaking in lime water, followed by boiling 
  • Parboiling - for large-scale detoxification

In the case of neurolathyrism, administration of vitamin C at doses of 500-1000 mg may help reverse the damage.

Related Pearl: Food adulteration diseases

Food Adulterant Toxin Disease
Dal Khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus) BOAA* Lathyrism
Oil Argemone mexicana (oil) Sanguinarine Epidemic dropsy
Millet Crotalaria seeds (Jhunjhunia) Pyrrolizidine alkaloids
(Hepatotoxic)		 Endemic ascites 
Bajra, wheat Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Ergotism

 * BOAA-Beta Oxalyl Amino Alanine

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins play a role in Kreb's cycle?

choices.text: Vitamins B1, B2, B3 and B5
Vitamins B1, B3, B6 and B12
Vitamins B2, B3, B5 and B6
Vitamins B3, B6, B12 and B5

questions.solution:
Vitamins B1, B2, B3, and B5 of the vitamin B complex play a role in Kreb's cycle.

The following vitamins serve as cofactors for various enzymes of the tricarboxylic acid(TCA) cycle –

  • Vitamin B1: Thiamine
    • Active form - thiamine diphosphate
    • Cofactor for decarboxylation step of alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex.
  • Vitamin B2: Riboflavin
    • Active form - FAD (flavin adenine dinucleotide)
    • Cofactor for succinate dehydrogenase
  • Vitamin B3: Niacin
    • Active form - NAD+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide)
    • Cofactor for isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and malate dehydrogenase complex
  • Vitamin B5: Pantothenic acid
    • Active form - as a part of coenzyme A
    • Cofactor for esterified to the carboxylic acid residues, i.e. acetyl-CoA and succinyl-CoA.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: A known alcoholic patient is brought to the emergency in a disoriented state. He complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin. Which of the following should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards delirium tremens likely due to acute alcohol withdrawal. Lorazepam + thiamine should be given to this patient.

Delirium tremens occurs after 2-4 days of abstinence in a heavy or chronic drinker. It is characterized by autonomic hyperactivity, tremors, delusions, and hallucinations. It usually resolves spontaneously in 7 days but may cause the death of the patient due to cardiovascular collapse or infections or self-injury.

Delirium tremens is treated using benzodiazepines starting with a higher dosage which is gradually tapered as withdrawal symptoms disappear. In cases of chronic alcohol use, vitamin deficiency (especially thiamine) may be co-existing and hence bolus doses of thiamine are given to prevent/treat Wernicke encephalopathy.

Haloperidol is generally not the first-line drug in case of alcoholic withdrawal. It might be used as an add-on in agitated patients. It decreases the seizure threshold and its use would be appropriate in a case of co-existing psychotic disorder like schizophrenia.

                             Drug Therapy For Alcohol Intoxication and Withdrawal
Clinical Problem Drug Route  Dosage
Tremulousness and mild to moderate agitation

Chlordiazepoxide

Diazepam

Oral

Oral

25-100 mg every 4-6 hrs

5-20 mg every 4-6 hrs
Hallucinosis Lorazepam Oral 2-10 mg every 4-6 hrs
Extreme agitation Chlordiazepoxide Intravenous 0.5 mg/kg at 12 mg/min
Withdrawal seizures Diazepam Intravenous 0.15 mg/kg at 2.5 mg/min
Delirium tremens Lorazepam Intravenous 0.1 mg/kg at 2.0 mg/min

questions.text:
Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely to result in anemia?
  1. Vitamin B1
  2. Vitamin B6
  3. Vitamin E
  4. Vitamin B9
  5. Vitamin B5
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, anemia is most likely to be seen in deficiencies of vitamin B6, vitamin E, and vitamin B9.

Vitamin B6 deficiency can result in sideroblastic anemia as vitamin B6 acts as a cofactor for the enzyme Aminolevulinate synthase which is involved in Heme synthesis.


Vitamin E acts as a lipid-soluble antioxidant in cell membranes. In vitamin E deficiency, the erythrocyte membranes are abnormally fragile as a result of lipid peroxidation, leading to hemolytic anemia.

Vitamin B9(Folate) deficiency or vitamin B12 deficiency which leads to functional folate deficiency affects cells that are dividing rapidly because they have a large requirement for thymidine for DNA synthesis. Clinically, this affects the bone marrow, leading to megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presented with complaints of pain in her left calf and thigh muscles. Doppler ultrasonography revealed deep vein thrombosis. She was started on enoxaparin. A week later, enoxaparin was discontinued, and was started on warfarin. Two months later she returned with complaints of severe nose bleed. Her INR was 7.0. To prevent severe hemorrhage, warfarin should be discontinued, and the patient should be immediately started on which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Warfarin should be immediately discontinued, and vitamin K1 should be started to accelerate the formation of the vitamin K-dependent factors.

Elevated level of international normalized ratio (INR) is suggestive of severe anticoagulation.

Reversal of Warfarin action:

  • Moderate anticoagulation caused by warfarin, without any bleeding can be treated with cessation of the drug alone.
  • An excessive anticoagulant effect and bleeding caused due to warfarin can be reversed by stopping the drug immediately and administering oral or parenteral vitamin K1 (phytonadione), fresh frozen plasma, prothrombin complex concentrates, and recombinant factor VIIa (rFVIIa).
  • In case of severe bleeding, administration of prothrombin complex or rFVIIa coupled with intravenous vitamin K, rapidly reverses the effect of warfarin.

questions.text: During your residency, the consultant advises you to treat an 8-year-old child, who presented with the following ocular finding, with intramuscular doses of Vitamin A. What should be your treatment plan according to WHO recommended schedule in this patient?

choices.text: 200,000 IU by intramuscular injection on Day 0, Day 1 and 4 weeks later
100,000 IU by intramuscular injection on Day 0, Day 1 and 4 weeks later
200,000 IU by intramuscular injection on Day 0, Day 7 and 4 weeks later
100,000 IU by intramuscular injection on Day 0, Day 7 and 4 weeks later

questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bitot spot which is a feature seen in vitamin A deficiency, which is treated by 100,000 IU by intramuscular injection on Day 0, Day 1, and 4 weeks later, according to WHO recommended schedule.

The WHO recommended schedule is as given below:

  • All patients above the age of 1 year (except women of reproductive age): 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU by intramuscular injection should be given immediately on diagnosis (day 0) and repeated the following day (day 1) and 4 weeks later.
  • Children under the age of 1 year and children of any age who weigh less than 8 kg should be treated with half the doses for patients of more than 1 year of age.
  • Women of reproductive age, pregnant or not;
    • Those having night blindness (XN), conjunctival xerosis (X1A), and Bitot’s spots (X1B) should be treated with a daily dose of 10,000 IU of vitamin A orally (1 sugar-coated tablet) for 2 weeks.
    • For corneal xerophthalmia, administration of a full dosage schedule (described for patients above 1 year of age) is recommended.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text:
An elderly patient on a vegetarian diet presenting with easy fatigability and pallor was investigated. Peripheral smear showed findings of macrocytic anemia. What is the probable cause of anemia in this patient? Other lab findings are as follows:

Hemoglobin - 9 g/dL

Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) - 112 fL

Serum homocysteine - Elevated

Serum methylmalonic acid - Normal
questions.solution:
The probable cause of anemia in this patient of folate deficiency.

The given clinical scenario of macrocytic anemia in a vegetarian with elevated homocysteine levels is due to megaloblastic anemia, which can be caused by the deficiency of vitamin B12 or folic acid. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with raised serum methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels, which are normal in this patient; hence, folic acid deficiency is the cause of megaloblastic anemia in this patient.

Folic acid deficiency is associated with the following clinical and laboratory findings:

  • Raised MCV (normal range: 80–100 fL) - macrocytosis
  • Normal MCHC (normal range: 33–36 g/dL) 
  • Increased MCH
  • Elevated RDW
  • Decreased reticulocyte count - due to destruction of abnormal erythroid precursors
  • Elevated homocysteine level
  • Normal MMA level

where MCV, mean corpuscular volume; MCHC, mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration; mean corpuscular hemoglobin, MCH; RDW, red cell distribution width

In vitamin B12 deficiency, neurological abnormalities, elevated homocysteine, and elevated MMA levels are seen. 

Related Pearl: Morphological Classification of Anemias

(MCV <80 fl)

(MCV 80 - 100 fl)

Macrocytic Normochromic

(MCV >100 fl)

Thalassemia

Acute blood loss

Anemia of renal disease

Hemolysis*

Bone marrow suppression

  • Aplastic anemia
  • Pure red cell aplasia

 

  

Megaloblastic:

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Folate deficiency

Thiamine deficiency

Drugs - Methotrexate, Zidovudine, hydroxyurea

Orotic aciduria

 

Non-megaloblastic:

Alcohol use

Liver disease

Hypothyroidism

Hemolysis*

 

*Hemolysis can be associated with macrocytosis because of compensatory reticulocytosis. However, MCV can be normal depending on the degree of hemolysis.

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia. 

Related Pearl: Difference between B12 and Folic acid Deficiency

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with steatorrhea, hemolytic anemia, and ataxia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given below. Which vitamin can particularly prevent early death in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette mentioning steatorrhea, hemolytic anemia, and ataxia along with acanthocytes seen in the peripheral blood smear is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia. Administration of large doses of particularly Vitamin E can prevent early death in this condition.

Abetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to loss of function mutation in the gene encoding microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP). MTP transfers lipids to nascent chylomicrons in the intestine and VLDLs in the liver. Therefore, when the MTP gene is mutated, chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL are not produced.

Vitamin E and retinyl esters are normally transported from enterocytes to the liver by chylomicrons. Vitamin E is also dependent on VLDL for transport out of the liver and into circulation. Because of the inability of these patients to secrete apoB-containing particles, patients with abetalipoproteinemia are markedly deficient in vitamin E. 

Features of abetalipoproteinemia include diarrhea, failure to thrive, neurological features like loss of deep tendon reflexes, dysmetria, ataxia, spastic gait, etc, hypolipidemia, and progressive pigmented retinopathy which may progress to near-blindness.

Treatment of this condition includes the administration of large doses of Vitamin E. They are also mild to moderately deficient in vitamins A and K, those vitamins need to be administrated as well.

Note: It is necessary to initiate Vitamin E therapy as early as possible to prevent the development of neurologic sequelae which may warrant even higher doses of vitamin E.

questions.text: Tryptophan loading test is done to detect deficiency of:
questions.solution:
The tryptophan load test is done to detect the deficiency of pyridoxal phosphate (vitamin B6).

In the catabolism of tryptophan through the kynurenine anthranilate pathway, the enzyme kynureninase requires pyridoxal phosphate as a coenzyme for converting  3-OH Kynurenine to further sequential compounds in tryptophan catabolism. In pyridoxol phospahate deficiency, 3-OH Kynurenine is converted to xanthurenic acid, which is excreted in the urine.

Hence, to detect B6 deficiency, tryptophan is given and xanthurenic acid is tested in the urine.

questions.text: FIGLU (Formiminoglutamic acid) excretion test is used in the assessment of the deficiency of which of the following vitamins?
questions.solution:
FIGLU excretion test is used in the assessment of deficiency of Vitamin B9 (Folic acid).

FIGLU is converted to L-glutamate by the enzyme glutamate formimino transferase. This enzyme uses folate (vitamin B9). In Vitamin B9 deficiency, FIGLU accumulates in the body and is excreted in the urine.

Folic acid is a water-soluble vitamin, and its active form is tetrahydrofolate (THFA). It acts as a carrier of one-carbon groups. These one-carbon groups are attached either to the 5th, 10th, or both 5th and 10th nitrogen atoms of THFA.

The methyl group in N5-methyl THFA is used for the synthesis of active methionine. This takes part in transmethylation reactions required for the synthesis of choline, epinephrine, creatine, etc.

Folate deficiency results in

  • Reduced synthesis of DNA
  • Macrocytic anemia
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia
  • Neural tube defects in the fetus like spina bifida

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with nutritional melalgia?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic acid/ Vitamin B5 deficiency leads to burning feet syndrome, also known as nutritional melalgia or Gopalan's syndrome.

It acts as a functional part of CoA or acyl carrier protein. CoA plays a role in fatty acid oxidation, the citric acid cycle, acetylations, and cholesterol synthesis. ACP is involved in the fatty acid synthesis.

Deficiency leads to peripheral nerve damage leading to burning foot syndrome. It is mostly seen during a famine, in prison camps, in chronic alcoholics, and in renal dialysis patients.

questions.text: What does the term folate trap refer to?
questions.solution:
The term folate trap refers to accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate with deficiency of tetrahydrofolate. It is seen in vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor of methionine synthase, an enzyme involved in the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl-tetrahydrofolate. Hence, vitamin B12 deficiency leads to folate deficiency.

Since vitamin B12 is also linked to regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, there is hyperhomocysteinemia as well. It increases the risk of atherosclerosis, hypertension and thrombosis.

questions.text:
The given condition can occur due to the deficiency of:

1. Iron

2. Vitamin A

3. Riboflavin

4. Vitamin D

5. Vitamin E

6. Essential fatty acids.
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple papules on elbows having a follicular distribution. This is known as phrynoderma or "toad-skin" which can occur due to the deficiency of vitamin A, B complex, riboflavin, vitamin C, vitamin E, and essential fatty acids. Options 2, 3, 5, and 6 are correct.

It manifests as groups of papules with a central keratotic plug. The commonest sites are elbows and knees. They are present around the follicles and give the skin a rough texture.

Treatment involves the correction of poor diet and administration of a multivitamin preparation containing vitamin A.

Other options

 Iron deficiency leads to anemia. Dermatological manifestations of iron deficiency are:

  • Brittle nails with longitudinal ridges- in moderate deficiency
  • Koilonychia- spoon-shaped nails in severe deficiency. It commonly affects third and fourth nails.
  • Atrophic tongue, glossodynia (pain in the tongue), aphthous and angular stomatitis.
  • Brittle, dry, and lustreless hair

Deficiency of vitamin D and calcium results in poor mineralization of bone leading to rickets. There may be fraying and widening of the metaphysis, prominent costochondral joints (rachitic rosary), craniotabes, bowing of the lower extremities, frontal bossing, scoliosis, fractures, and dental anomalies. The only cutaneous manifestation of vitamin D deficiency is alopecia.

Related Pearl: Fat-soluble vitamins

questions.text: A student, soon after finishing his final year in college, joins a fitness centre and starts eating raw eggs for protein. He started developing fatigue on moderate exercise. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in him?
questions.solution:
The consumption of raw egg white induces symptoms of biotin deficiency.

Raw egg white contains a glycoprotein known as avidin, which tightly binds to biotin and renders it unabsorbable from the intestine. Hence, there can be a biotin deficiency state.

Biotin deficiency may cause:

  • Dermatitis
  • Mental status changes (depression, hallucinations)
  • Hyperesthesia
  • Atrophic glossitis

In infants, biotin deficiency presents as hypotonia, lethargy, and apathy. In addition, infants may develop alopecia and a characteristic rash that includes the ears.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Riboflavin (B2)

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with intermittent upper abdominal pain for 4 months, episodic hot flushes involving the face and upper chest for 2 months, and watery stools 5–6 episodes per day for 1 month.CT abdomen shows a mass in the terminal ileum. The resected specimen is positive for synaptophysin. Which of the following vitamin deficiency can occur as a result of the above condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a history of intermittent upper abdominal pain, episodic hot flushes, watery diarrhea, and the resected specimen staining positive for synaptophysin are diagnostic of carcinoid syndrome. In carcinoid syndrome there is an overproduction of 5-hydroxytryptamine which may account for as much as 60% of the body’s tryptophan metabolism, causing pellagra because of the diversion away from niacin synthesis. 

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, found mostly among people eating corn/maize-based diets, which are low in niacin and tryptophan. Excess leucine in jowar and maize disrupts the conversion of tryptophan to niacin.

The 4Ds of pellagra:

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia
  • Death

It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone.

It is treated by oral supplementation of 100–200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid 3 times daily for 5 days.

Carcinoid syndrome is a systemic disorder characterized by diarrhea, skin rashes, bronchospasm, tumors in the gastrointestinal tract, flushing, and cyanosis. The pathogenesis is mediated by components like serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine), bradykinin, tachykinin, histamine, and prostaglandins. The tumors arise from Kulchitsky cells.

Immunohistochemical (IHC) markers for carcinoid tumors are:

  • Neuron-specific enolase
  • Synaptophysin
  • Chromogranin A

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presents with pinpoint ecchymoses around the hair follicles and multiple episodes of epistaxis. On examination, he has nodules as seen in the image given below, which are tender on palpation. All of the following radiological signs could be seen in this patient, except ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of perifollicular hemorrhages and the image showing scorbutic rosary are suggestive of scurvy. The radiological sign cupping and fraying is not seen in this patient. It is seen in rickets. 

Radiological signs in scurvy include:

  • White line of Frankel: Calcified cartilage at metaphyses
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelkan spur: Lateral prolongation of the white line, which is present at the cortical ends
  • Wimberger ring sign: Circular, opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline. Hence, deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in generalized bleeding tendencies.

Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include:

  • Petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points
  • Epistaxis
  • Gum bleeding
  • Perifollicular hemorrhages

Other manifestations are: 

  • Poor wound and fracture healing
  • Hyperkeratosis of hair follicles
  • Arthralgia and muscle weakness
  • Defective osteoid formation
  • Costo-chondral separation leading to the formation of sharply angulated tender nodules or scorbutic rosary

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text:
Which of the following are vitamin B12-dependent enzymes?

1. Methyl malonyl CoA mutase
2. Homocysteine synthase
3. Folate reductase
4. Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
Among the given enzymes, 1 and 4 i.e., methyl malonyl CoA mutase and methionine synthase are vitamin B12-dependent enzymes. 

Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Its absorption in the terminal ileum is facilitated by the presence of intrinsic factor, produced by parietal cells in the stomach. There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase) - catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase - methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA

The image below shows B12 serving as a cofactor of methionine synthase.

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF (methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by the methioninesynthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate, which cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap. The folate cycle acts as the link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, and a deficiency of vitamin B12 can cause a functional deficiency of folate.

The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine. Since vitamin B12 is also linked to the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, its deficiency can result in hyperhomocysteinemia as well.

Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Biotin (B7)

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiency do not cause Hyperhomocysteinemia?
questions.solution:
Niacin deficiency does not cause hyperhomocysteinemia.

Elevated blood homocysteine is a significant risk factor for atherosclerosis, thrombosis, and hypertension. The condition is the result of deficiency of Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6), Cobalamin (B12), and folate resulting in failure to convert homocysteine to methionine thus hyperhomocysteinemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with hypertriglyceridemia is considered for niacin therapy. She is a known diabetic managed adequately with sugars well under control. Why should niacin be used cautiously in this patient?

choices.text: It can cause scleroderma which makes injecting insulin difficult.
It can increase the metabolism of oral hypoglyemic drugs.

questions.solution:
Niacin should be used cautiously in diabetics as it can cause hyperglycemia.

Niacin induces insulin resistance and also decreases glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which may result in severe hyperglycemia. When niacin is prescribed for patients with known or suspected diabetes, blood glucose levels should be monitored at least once a week.

questions.text: A young woman is being evaluated for anemia. The oral and eye examination findings are shown below. Which of the following investigations will be useful in diagnosing the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with its image showing cheilosis, angular stomatitis, a magenta-colored tongue, and corneal vascularisation, points to the diagnosis of riboflavin deficiency. RBC glutathione reductase activity will be useful in diagnosing this condition.

Riboflavin provides the reactive moieties of the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD). The main dietary sources of riboflavin are milk and dairy products.

The following signs and symptoms characterize the deficiency state of riboflavin:

  • Cheilosis- pallor in the angle of the mouth and fissuring of the lips, which extends radially to the skin.
  • Glossitis- the tongue becomes smooth, and there is a loss of papillae (magenta-colored tongue).
  • Eyes- keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation.
  • Other features- seborrheic dermatitis and anemia.

Note: Because of its intense yellow color, riboflavin is widely used as a food additive.

Other options:

Option A: RBC transketolase assay diagnoses vitamin B1/ thiamine deficiency. Thiamine deficiency mainly manifests as peripheral neuritis, beriberi, and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis.

Option B: The serum methyl malonate level is used to diagnose vitamin B12/ methylcobalamin deficiency. Patients typically present with anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and signs and symptoms of subacute combined degeneration, manifesting as loss of vibration and proprioception and absent deep tendon reflexes.

Option C: The RBC transaminase assay assesses glutamate levels inside RBCs. Human erythrocytes require a continual supply of glutamate to support glutathione synthesis, but this is not routinely tested.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)
